div.p: THE Church-Catechiſm ENLARG'D and EXPLAIN'D, IN AN Eaſie and Familiar METHOD, WITH THE SCRIPTURE-PROOFS Annexed thereunto.
div.q: Theſe words which I command thee this day ſhall be in thine Heart. And thou ſhalt teach them diligently unto thy Children, and ſhalt talk of them when thou ſitteſt in thy houſe, and when thou walkeſt by the way, and when thou lyeſt down, and when thou riſeſt up. Deut. 6.7, 8.
div.p: LONDON, Printed for Thomas Parkhurſt, at the Bible and Three Crowns, at the lower end of Cheapſide, near Mercers Chappel. 1697.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: THIS explication of the Catechiſm ſuppoſeth the Reader to be convinc'd of the neceſſity and excellency of the Duty of Catechizing; and the great danger of the neglect thereof, in Churches or Familys where there are any that need training up in the way that they ſhould go.

I am not ignorant that there are many who have written excellently on the Catechiſm; and no wonder, when ſo much of every Miniſters time is or ought to be taken up in the uſe of it. But yet there are not many that have made uſe of this Method; The firſt Deſigner of it, being taken away, as is ſaid in his life, before He had accompliſh't what He intended, was followed by Doctor Wallis upon another Catechiſm: Doctor Comber, and (I think) He alone followed him upon this: yet He by deſigning ſo much brevity and altogether omitting the Scripture proofs hath left room for a further Eſſay.

The uſe of this Mothod is double. (1.) As to the meaneſt capacitys it hath a viſible benefit, in that the Queſtion is ſo fram'd as to lead the perſon inſtructed to his Anſwer, whereby his underſtanding is both try'd and inform'd and yet the memory not burden'd with words; it being evident that many of the more careleſs ſort are frighted from the Catechiſm by a long Anſwer impos'd upon the memory: and others get words by vote which they underſtand not and preſently ſinger. I only here deſire of the Teacher, that when He propounds or as be any Queſtion, He would not expreſs or recite the Text or Texts of Scripture annexed thereunto; partly becauſe theſe proofs do indeed belong to the Anſwer, and not to the Queſtion, though they could not conveniently be places
otherwiſe than they are; and partly, becauſe ſuch a recital of the Texts, Chapter and Verſe would make the Queſtion ſo long as to hinder the attention of the Learner: great care being to be taken that He Anſwers underſtandingly, and not by gheſs, Yes or No: and for that reaſon He may ſometimes be required to repeat the matter of the Queſtion in his Anſwer; as Q. Are there more Gods than One? A. No, there are not more Gods than One. (2.) The other uſe is for them that have more underſtanding, who muſt be obliged to anſwer to the Queſtion, by the Scripture annexed; in this manner. Q. Are there more Gods than One? A. No. Q. How prove you that? A. From Deut. 6.4. Hear O Iſrael the Lord thy God is one Lord, and I think, it cannot be deny'd, that the beſt as well as eaſieſt way of Learning Scripture-principles is in Scripture Phraſe. Thoſe lively Oracles make a deeper and more abiding impreſſion than any other words: And the prudent Catechiſt may with his Pen mark in every Section ſuch Texts for the Learner to recite at a time as He ſhall judge for plainneſs or number to be ſuited to his Capacity.

Nor will this hinder the Learning theſe Principles in diſtinct propoſitions as they are ſet down in other Catechiſms; but will make it far more eaſie to Learn the words, when they are by this inſtructed beforehand in the matter therein contain'd.

In this Compoſure I have endeavoured to make the Queſtions very Comprehenſive, by crowding thereinto as much matter, as would conſiſt with the plainneſs that I ſtudiouſly deſign'd: ſo that there is enough in each Queſtion, eſpecially when the proof is given in Anſwer, for the Catechiſt to dilate and enlarge upon, in his more Familiar Inſtructing of thoſe committed to his Charge.
May the whole be for the Glory of God through Christ, and for the Edification of his Flock, particularly the Lambs therein.

div.head: A CATECHISM: That is to ſay, An Inſtruction to be learned of every Perſon before He be brought to be Confirmed by the Biſhop.
div.p: N. or M.

p.hi: By Godfathers and Godmothers in my Baptiſm, wherein I was made a Member of Chriſt, the Child of God, and an Inheritor of the Kingdom of Heaven.

row.cell: §. WAS not your Name given you at your Baptiſm, as they were wont to receive their Names at their Circumciſion? Luke 2.21.
Is it not in the power of Parents (chiefly of Fathers) to give Names to their Children? Luke 1.60, 62.
Is it then unlawful for others, by the Parents Conſent to do it, as Godfathers and Godmothers amongſt us? Ruth 4.17.
§. ARE Infants incapable of receiving any Priviledges or Benefits by Baptiſm? Mark 10.14.
(1.) Are there not certain outward Priviledges confer'd by Baptiſm, as of old, by Circumciſion? Rom. 3.1, 2.
* Were you not by Baptiſm made a Member of Chriſt, i. e. of his Body, the Church? 1 Cor. 6.15. & 12.13.
But have all ſuch Members of Chriſt a ſaving intereſt in him, or benefit by him? John 15.2.
* VVere you not thereby made the Child of God? Acts 3.25. Rom. 9.4.
And are there not many viſible Children of God, that prove rebels againſt him? Iſa. 1.2. Ezek. 16.20.
* VVere you not further admitted an Heir, or inheritour of the Kingdom of Heaven? Eph. 3.6.
And are there not many viſible Heirs or Children of the Kingdom that ſhall be caſt out? Mat. 8.12.
† Is there then any Reaſon why they that live in Sin, ſhould boaſt of, or reſt in, theſe outward Priviledges? Mat. 3.9.
(2.) Are there not alſo inward and ſpiritual priviledges offered in Baptiſm, and ſealed on Gods part to Believers? Gal. 3.26, 27.
Are theſe beſtowed on you without any Conditions required on your part? Mark 16.16.
Do the conditions and terms of the Goſpel make the Grace therein not to be free? Eph. 2.8.
† Are you not then by Baptiſm under an engagement to perform the Goſpel-conditions? 1 Pet. 3.21.

p.hi: What did your Godfathers and Godmothers then for you?

div.p: They did promiſe and vow thrée things in my Name; Firſt, That I ſhould renounce the Devil and all his Works, the Pomps and Vanity of this wicked World, and all the ſinful Luſts of the Fleſh. Secondly, That I ſhould believe all the Articles of the Chriſtian Faith. And Thirdly, That I ſhould keep Gods holy Will and Commandments, and walk in the ſame all the days of my Life.

row.cell: §. DID your Sureties ſay, when you were Baptized, that you did ſo repent and believe?
Did they promiſe in their own Name, or bind their own Souls with a Vow, that you ſhould do ſo when you came to Age?
Did they not then in your Name promiſe, or declare the Vow that you ſhould be bound to perform? Luke 5.18-20.
If you had been Baptized at Age, ſhould you not in your own Name have made the Promiſe?

† VVhoever then made the Profeſſion in your Name,
do you not now acknowledge it was your Promiſe and your Vow? Pſalm 119.106.
§. IS not the Baptiſmal Vow to Renounce and forſake all your Spiritual Enemies?
(1.) Muſt you not Renounce the Devil, under whoſe Power you were by Nature? Eph. 2.2.
Is it enough to Renounce the Worſhip of the Devil, which is practiſed by Idolaters, 1 Cor. 10.20, and by Wizards and Charmers? Deut. 18.10, 11, 12.
Muſt you not renounce and reſiſt him as an Adverſary and a tempter, with all his works? Jam. 4.7.
* Muſt you not renounce the Suggeſtions of Satan and his inſtruments, which are the works that He practiſeth for your ruin? Eph. 2.2.

* Muſt you not renounce the works that Signally bear the Devils Image, 1 Joh. 3.8. Such as, Lying. Joh. 8.44. pride. 1 Tim. 3.6. Malice. Eph. 4.26, 27. Treachery. Joh. 6.70, 71. and the Seducing others. Acts 13.10?
(2.) Is not the world another Enemy that you are bound to renounce? Gal. 1.4. 1 Joh. 5.4.
Are you bound to leave the Society of men, and to dwell alone in woods and rocks; or to renounce your Callings and Eſtates, and vow Poverty? Acts 20.35.
* Muſt we not renounce the examples, flatterys and enticings of wicked men? Rom. 12 2. Prov. 1.10.
May we then like the Company, or have a voluntary Fellowſhip with notoriouſly ungodly men? Eph. 5.11.
* Muſt we not renounce the things of the world, ſo far as they are contrary to Chriſt, or would draw us from him? Luke 14.26.
Did not the firſt Chriſtians renounce by the name of Pomps and Vanities, the Pompous ſhews in the Pagan Theatres and Proceſſions?
* May we then be allowed to frequent prophane Stage-plays, or the revels in Wakes and drunken Feſtivals? Gal. 5.21.
* May we immoderately or unſeaſonably ſeek or affect the riches, honours, or pleaſures of the world? 1 Joh. 2.15, 16.
(3.) Is not the fleſh with the ſinful luſts thereof the other enemy that we muſt renounce? Gal. 5.24.

Is not original Sin and corruption the fountain of all
actual Sins call'd the works of the fleſh? Jam. 1.14. Gal. 5.19-22.

Doth it no •
luſt againſt the Spirit and draw even the Members of the body to Sin? Gal. 5.17. Rom. 6.19.
* May we then follow the depraved dictates and reaſonings of a fleſhly mind? Rom. 8.7. Col. 2.18.
* Muſt we not eſpecially abhor the groſs ſins, and fleſhly luſts that War againſt the Soul? 1 Pet. 2.11.
§. ARE we not to obſerve in our Baptiſmal Vow, what we are to believe, as well as what we are to renounce?
1. Are not the Holy Scriptures, (Acts 24.14.) and particularly the Articles of the Creed, the Doctrinal object of our Faith? Joh. 20.31.
Can we believe theſe without underſtanding their meaning, and ſome good eſteem of their excellency? Luk. 1.4.
* Muſt we not aſſent to the truth of theſe Articles, and live and dye in contending for the Faith? Acts 8.37. Jud. 3.
Is it enough to profeſs theſe Doctrines with the mouth, without believing with the Heart? Rom. 10.9, 10.
Is it enough to believe them implicitly, becauſe the Church believes them, without ever examining and trying them by the word? 1 Joh. 4.1.
* Muſt we not believe with application to our Hearts, particularly in what relates to Chriſt? Eph. 1.13.
2. Is not Chriſt Himſelf then, the immediate and Perſonal Object of our Faith, as a Mediator, appointed by God, and dying for us? Rom. 3.25.
* Is not Faith to receive Chriſt as offer'd in the Goſpel, Joh. 1.12. and to rely on his merits and righteouſneſs?
Is it enough then to aſſent to the Articles as true, without a conſent to the offers and terms of the Goſpel? Jam. 2.19, 20.
* Is not ſaving Faith wrought powerfully by the Spirit. Eph. 1.19. and doth it not work by love and all good fruits? Gal. 5.6. Jam. 2.18.
Is Faith then a ſtrong conceit or perſwaſion that Chriſt dy'd for you, though you live in ſin and were never humbled for it? Mat. 7.22, 23.
§. ARE we not further engag'd by the Baptiſmal Vow to a continual obedience to the Holy will of God?
Did you promiſe a ſinleſs Obedience, for the ends of the Covenant of Works? 1 Joh. 1.8, 9.
But is not ſincere Obedience to the will of God declared in his word, indiſpenſably required in the Covenant of Grace? Gal. 6.16. Jam. 1.25.
* Is not this new Obedience from the efficacy of the Spirit, and conſtraint of Divine Love? 2 Cor. 5.14, 15.
Yet are we forbidden to take Motives of our Obedience from fear of puniſhment or hope of reward? Jer. 32.40.
* Are not the ends of it, that God may be glorify'd. Mat. 5.16. Our Neighbour edify'd. 1 Pet. 3.1, 2. and our Selves made meet for Heaven? Col. 1.12.
Will God then accept of that partial Obedience, that comes from meer cuſtom and Education, and is done for ſelf-applauſe or pretence of merit? Gal. 2.16.
* Muſt not our Obedience be free and willing, without being griev'd at any of his Commands? 1 Joh. 5.3.
* Muſt it not be univerſal, with all the Heart, and with a reſpect to all his Commandments, and that in all our actions? Pſal. 119.128. Prov. 7.2.
* Muſt it not be conſtant, even all the days of our Lives? Luk. 1.74, 75.

p.hi: Doſt thou think that thou art bound to believe and to do, as they have promis'd for thee?

Yes verily; and by God's help ſo I will, and I heartily thank our Heavenly Father, that He hath called me to this State of Salvation, through Ieſus Chriſt our Saviour, and I pray unto God to give me his Grace, that I may continue in the ſame to my lives end.

row.cell: §. HAVE you conſidered your Solemn Vow and Promiſe made in Baptiſm? Luk. 14.28, 31.
Do you now in the preſence of God and this Congregation make a profeſſion of your ſtanding to your Baptiſmal Covenant? Joſh. 24.22, 27.

* You ſay you will now; but will you make this profeſſion
in the moſt difficult and coſtly circumſtances, when the glory of God is concern'd? Rev. 2.3, 4.
* Do you make this profeſſion only for hereafter, without ſetting about the performance preſently? Pſal. 119.60.
You ſay, you will, but can you do it, in your own ſtrength? 2 Cor. 3.5.
* Do you then profeſs this, in and by the help, ſtrength and aſſiſtance of God? Phil. 4.13.
And is God wanting to his Church as to ſufficiency of means for your help therein? Iſa. 5.4.
§. ARE all that live under the Goſpel outwardly called to the State of Salvation and knowledge of the means? Acts 13.26.
Are all under this common call, alſo called effectually and choſen? Mat. 22.14.
But can this outward call be refus'd, without the woful hazard of the Soul? Prov. 1.24, 26.
§. IS not the Goſpel-call a great priviledge; and muſt you not Solemnly thank God our Heavenly Father through Chriſt for it? Pſal. 147.19, 20.
Is there not great danger of being drawn from the State to which you are called, by damnable doctrines or practices? Heb. 10.38.
Can you then continue therein and be kept from revolting from your profeſſion without real grace? Heb. 13.9. Phil. 2.12, 13.
And if God gives you the firſt grace, is perſeverance therein of your Selves? Luk. 22.32.
§. WILL you then pray unto God for his Grace to prevent, and aſſiſt you and conſummate at laſt his work in you? Jam. 1.5. Phil. 1.6.
And muſt you not to prayer add the diligent uſe of all the means, that God has appointed? Mat. 25.29.
Are you willing for your further help, that I ſhould teach you what you are to believe and to do according to your promiſe? Heb. 5.12.

p.hi: Rehearſe the Articles of thy Belief.

div.p: I Believe in God the Father Almighty, maker of Heaven and Earth: And in Ieſus Chriſt his only Son our Lord, Who was conceived by the Holy Ghoſt, Born of the Virgin Mary, Suffered under Pontius Pilate, Was crucifyed, dead and buried, he deſcended into Hell, The third day he roſe again from the dead, He aſcended into Heaven, And ſitteth on the right hand of God the Father Almighty, From thence he ſhall come to judge the Quick and the Dead. I believe in the Holy Ghoſt, The Holy Catholick Church, the Communion of Saints, The forgiveneſs of Sins, The reſurrection of the body, And the life everlaſting. Amen.

row.cell: §. IS this Creed found in ſo many words, any where, in Scripture?
Yet is not the whole of it proved by Scripture, as being according to the Doctrine of the Apoſtles, and therefore called the Apoſiles Creed? Eph. 2.20.
Is it not agreeable to Scripture that there ſhould be ſuch a Form of ſound Words? 2 Tim. 1.13.
* May we receive any thing as an Article of Faith that is not found in Scripture? Gal. 1.8, 9.
Are not all things revealed in the Scriptures, to be believed by us? Luk. 1.1.
But are all things therein alike neceſſary to be known? Joh. 17.3.
* Are not all things neceſſary and Fundamental plainly revealed? Pſal. 119.105.
* Were not the Scriptures confirm'd by Miracles, owned by the Church in all Ages; and are they not known by their majeſty, purity, and efficacy on the Hearts of Believers? Pſal. 19.7, 8, 9.
† Will you not then ſearch the Scriptures to prove the Articles of your Belief? Joh. 5.39.

div.p: Qu. What is the firſt Article?
Anſw. I believe in God the Father Almighty, Maker of Heaven and Earth.

row.cell:
§. DOTH not Believing in God denote a practical truſting in, and depending on Father Son and
Holy Ghoſt, as our Father, Redeemer and Sanctifyer?
Can this be without underſtanding what God hath revealed concerning himſelf, as ſtanding in theſe Relations to us? Heb. 11.6.
§. DO you not believe that there is a God, a moſt pure and ſupream Spirit? Joh. 4.24.
Hath He a body or bodily parts, or can He be ſeen with mortal eyes? 1 Tim. 1.17. Deut. 4.15.
Is He not infinite in his being and bleſſedneſs? Exod. 3.13.
Is He confin'd to Time or place? Pſal. 90.1. or doth He ſtand in need of any of his Creatures to make Him happy? Acts 17.25.
Is He ſubject to change or alteration? Jam. 1.17.
Can his attributes and glorious perfections be fully comprehended by us? Job 11.7, 8, 9.
Is He not moſt Holy, Powerful, Wiſe, Good, Juſt and true; and this Originally and independently ſo as no Creature can be? Mat. 19.17.
§. ARE there more Gods than One? Deut. 6.4. Is it agreeable to right reaſon that there ſhould be more than one firſt Cauſe, on which all things depend? Acts 17.28.
§. ARE there not three Perſons in the Godhead, the Father, the Son and the Holy Ghoſt? 1 Joh. 5.7.
Is either of theſe Divine Perſons before or after, greater or leſs than the other? Joh. 10.30.
Have they not one and the ſame Divine nature, and are they not diſtinguiſhed by their Perſonal properties?
Did not the Father from eternity beget the Son, Pſal. 2.7. and is not the Son begotten of the Father before all worlds? Joh. 1.14.
Doth not the Holy Ghoſt proceed from the Father and the Son? Joh. 15.26.
§. DID not the Almighty power of God appear in the works of his Creation? Iſa. 45.12, 13.
* Did He not make all things of nothing, by the word of his power, in the ſpace of 6 days? Heb. 11.3. Pſal. 33.6. Gen. 1.1.
Did He make any thing amiſs? Gen. 1.31.
† And doth He not by his providence uphold and govern all that He hath made? Heb. 1.3.
* Did He not in particular make man, his body Form'd of the duſt, and his Soul immediately inſpir'd? Gen. 2.7.
Did not God create him after his own Image, a knowing, holy creature, able alſo to ſulfil the whole Law? Gen. 1.26.
Did not God Covenant with man to confirm his life and happineſs, upon condition of his perfect obedience? Rom. 10.5.
Was the particular command given to try his obedience (viz. that He ſhould not eat of the tree of Knowledge of good and evil) a hard and impoſſible thing?
Did not God threaten death on his diſobedience. Gen. 2.17.
Should man have dy'd, if he had not ſinned. Rom. 5.12.
Did not man underſtand and agree to his Covenant? Gen. 3.3.

div.p: Qu. What is the Second Article?
Anſw. And in Jeſus Chriſt His only Son, our Lord.

row.cell: §. DO you not Believe in God the Son, the Second Perſon of the Trinity, equal with the Father and partaker of the ſame eſſence? Phil. 2.6.
Though Believers are called Sons by Grace and adoption? 1 Joh. 3.1. Yet is not our Lord His only Son by Nature and Eternal Generation? Rom. 8.3.
§. IS not the Son of God called Jeſus becauſe He ſaves his People from their Sins? Mat. 1.21.
* Was man confirm'd in the holy eſtate in which He was created, as the Elect Angels are now?
Did He not fall from that eſtate by Tranſgreſſing the Law and command which God gave him? Eccl. 7.29.
Did He not Sin by the temptation of the Devil, being left to the freedom of his own will? Gen. 3 4, 5, 6.
Can ſo high an affront to the majeſty of the Lawgiver, that contain'd ſo much Infidelity and ſuch a total defection from God, be reckoned a ſmall Sin?
* Was not Adam our common Father, a publick Perſon and our Repreſentative in the Covenant of works? 1 Cor. 15.22. Rom. 5.12, 19.
Are there then any meer men that are not guilty of Adam's firſt ſin, and lyable to wrath thereupon? Rom. 5.18. Eph. 2.3.
Is not our nature by the fall corrupted by Original Sin, from whence all actual Tranſgreſſions flow? Pſal. 51.5.
And is there any ſin that doth not deſerve death and eternal Damnation? Rom. 6.23.
* Has God left all the poſterity of Adam to periſh in this State, into which they brought themſelves?
Having choſen ſome before all time. Eph. 1.4. hath He not ••• red into a new Covenant with them, called the Covenant of Grace? Ezek. 16.8.
Is man left to ſave Himſelf by his own wiſdom or power? Hoſ. 13.9.
Or, is there any other Redeemer from this State of ſin and wrath, but our Lord Jeſus Chriſt? Acts 4.12.
* Did not the Son of God that He might Redeem us, become man and take on him a true body and reaſonable Soul? Heb. 2.14.
Is He not then one Perſon in two Natures?
If He had not been man could He have dyed, and if He had not been God could he have Merited by dying? Acts 20.28.
§. IS not this Jeſus the Chriſt or Meſſias, ſo long promiſed and expected? Job. 8.24.
Is He not called Chriſt becauſe anointed to His Offices by the Spirit, which He received without meaſure? Pſal. 45.7. Joh. 3.34.
(1.) Were not Prophets anointed. 1 Kings 19.16. and had not He the Office of a Prophet? Acts 3.21.
Could we have known the will of God, if his only begotten Son had not revealed it? Joh. 1.18.
Did He not at firſt preach himſelf, and afterwards ſend Paſtors and Teachers, to ſhew us the whole counſel of God touching our Salvation? Eph. 4.11.
But is the outward Preaching ſufficient without the inward effectual Teachings of the Spirit? Joh. 6.45.
(2.) Were not the Legal Prieſts anointed. Exod. 40.13. and Hath not our Lord the Office of a Prieſt? Pſal. 110.4.
* Was not his human nature, Soul and Body, offer'd up a Sacrifice to ſatisfie the Divine Juſtice? Iſa. 53.10. Heb. 9.13, 14.
Was this Sacrifice offer'd more than once; or, is it offer'd dayly in the Maſs? Heb. 9.28.
* Doth He not now appear in Heaven to make interceſſion for us? Heb. 7.24, 25.
(3.) Were not Kings alſo anointed. 1 Sam. 10.1. and hath not He the Office of a King? Pſal. 2.6.
Can any defend the Church, Deliver it, and Conquer the Enemies thereof but He? Rev. 17.14.
Hath He not ſubdued Subjects to himſelf, erected Officers, and made Laws to govern his Church by? Pſal. 110.3.
Is He not rightly Stiled Lord, as being rightful Soveraign; and our Lord by right of Redemption, and our Reſignation of our Selves to him? Rom. 14.9.

div.p: Qu. What is the Third Article?
Auſw. Who was conceived by the Holy Ghoſt, born of the Virgin Mary.

row.cell: §. DID He take upon Him the nature of the Angels? Heb. 2.16.
Had He when He took our nature any earthly Father? Luk. 3.23. Heb. 7.3.
* Was He not Conceived by the power of the Holy Ghoſt in the Womb of his Mother? Mat. 1.21.
Did not the Holy Ghoſt by that wonderful operation, ſanctifie and purifie that Subſtance of the Virgin, of which He was made man? Luk. 1.35.
Hath He then by taking on him the ſame Fleſh and Bloud that the Children have, the ſame Original Stain as they? Heb. 7.26.
And was not the Human Nature thus Form'd, in the moment of the Conception aſſum'd into the Perſon of the Son of God? Luk. 1.39.
Did He relinquiſh his Divine Nature, or was there a Converſion of the Godhead into Fleſh? Rom. 9.5.
But did He not veil his Divinity, when in our Fleſh He ſeem'd to many, to be no more than a man? Phil. 2.7.
And is not this wonderful Condeſcenſion, called his coming down from Heaven for us? Joh. 3.13.
† Are we capable of Comprehending fully the Myſtery of his Incarnation? 1 Tim. 3.13.
* Was it not according to the firſt promiſe, that He ſhould be the Seed of the Woman? Gen. 3.15.
Was He not born of a Virgin for further demonſtration of his power and purity? Iſa. 7.14.
And was He not born of the Virgin Mary, as being of the Tribe of Judah and Family of David? Rom. 1.3.
Was there any thing in his Birth, as to time or place, which did not fully agree with the Prophecies that went before? Gal. 4.4, Luke 2.4.
Was His Birth in Princes Courts or the ſplendour of Earthly Grandeut? Luk. 2.7
Yet did not the Heavenly Hoſt, and miraculous Star declare his Dignity? Mat. 2.2. Luk. 2.13.
* Did He diſdain to be made under the Law, or to ſubmit to the Ceremonial part thereof, particularly in Circumciſion? Gal. 4.4, 5. Luk. 2.21.
And was He not perfectly obedient to the whole moral Law? Mat. 3.15. and 5.17.

div.p: Qu. What is the Fourth Article?
Anſw. He ſuffered under Pontius Pilate, was Crucified, Dead and buried, He deſcended into Hell.

row.cell: §. DID not our Lord Suffer the penalty of the Law for Sinners, as well as Submit to the Commands of it? Iſa. 53.5.
* Was He not all his life time a Man of ſorrows, perſecuted, tempted, affronted, and Subject to all our natural and ſinleſs Infirmities? Iſa. 53.3. Heb. 4.15.
Yet in the midſt of the Sufferings of his life, did He forbear to Preach, work Miracles, and to go about doing good? Mat. 4.23. Acts 10.38.
* Was He not betray'd, forſaken, and deny'd: reviled, ſpit on, and buffetted: accuſed, arraigned, and condemned to death? Mat. 26 and 27.
Was it a ſmall matter that He ſuffered under Pontius Pilate (a man noted for cruelty? Luk. 13.1.) and by a Death which the Romans would inflict on none but their Slaves?
Was not the Croſs a painful, lingering, ſhameful and accurſed death? Heb. 12.2. Gal. 3.13.

* But was not his Soul-agony the bittereſt part of his
Suffering both in the Garden and on the Croſs? Mat. 26.38. and 27.46.
Did He not then, as the great propitiation, drink the Cup of Wrath, which we had deſerv'd? Iſa. 53.6, 10.
§. WAS He not really dead by a Separation of his Soul from his body? 1 Cor. 19.3. Luk. 23.46.
Could He be otherwiſe than dead, when upon the piercing his ſide there came out forthwith bloud and water? Joh. 19.37.
Did not the darkning of the Sun, the rending the Vail, the quaking of the Earth, and cleaving of the Rocks further confirm this tremendous myſtery? Mat. 27.51.
§. AND could there be a greater evidence of his death, than his being buried, in ſuch a manner as is recorded? Mat. 27.59.—66.
Yea, did not the place and circumſtances of his Burial contribute to the aſſurance of his following Reſurrection? Joh. 19.39, 40.
§. MAY we doubt of the truth of his deſcending into Hell becauſe there are variety of opinions about the meaning of it?
If upon his Reſurrection He was not left in Hell, Acts 2.30, 31. Is it not evident that He had firſt deſcended thither? Eph. 4.9.
* Is it any where certainly revealed, that He went into the Hell of the damned, amongſt the Spirits there?
But did He not by his death vanquiſh the powers of Hell and darkneſs? Col. 2.14.
* Is not the unſeen State, or condition of ſeparation of Soul and Body, call'd the Grave and Hell? 1 Cor. 15.55.
And can it be deny'd that He ſo deſcended into Hell as to continue for a time under the dominion of Death in a ſeparate State? Rom. 6.9.

div.p: Qu. What is the Fifth Article?
Anſw. The third day He aroſe again from the Dead.

row.cell: §. DID He always continue in that State of the dead, or ſo long as to ſee corruption? Pſal. 16.10.
* Conſidering who He was, and what was Prophecyed of Him, was it poſſible for the bands of death to hold him? Acts 2.24.
Did He not riſe again, by his own power? Joh. 10.17, 18. to dye no more? Rev. 1.18.
Did He not riſe, as an evidence of our diſcharge Rom. 4.25. and a pledge of our Reſurrection? 1 Cor. 15.20.
* Did He ſhew himſelf to all the people, when riſen, or to his enemies that had ſo long diſpiſed his miracles before? Acts 10.41.
Yet were they left altogether without convincing evidence of his Reſurrection? Mat. 28.2, 3, &c.
* Was He not ſeen by a ſufficient number of witneſſes, (even 500 at once) and that at divers places and times, after He was riſen from the Dead? 1 Cor. 15.6.
* Could they be deceiv'd by a Phantaſm or Apparition, when they did both handle and ſee, yea eat and drink with Him after his Reſurrection? Luk. 24.38, 39.
* Could ſo Miraculous a work as raiſing the Dead, for a deſign ſo contrary to Satan's Kingdom, be done by Magick or power of the Devil? Eph. 1.19, 20. Mat. 12.25.
* Could the Diſciples roll away the Stone from the Sepulchre, Steal away his Body, Strip it of the Gravecloths, and not awake the Watch or Guard of Souldiers?

* Is it likely that men noted for ſincerity, 1 Theſ. 2.10. would impoſe on the world in a matter of ſuch conſequence, for which they expos'd themſelves to all manner of perſecutions and death it ſelf? Acts 5.41.
* If there had been any deceit could it have been conceal'd from ſo many envious and watchful enemies, in ſo publick a concern? Acts 26.26.
* Did not the witneſſes of his Reſurrection confirm their report by undoubted Miracles? Heb. 2.4.
† Was not this Reſurrection on the third day from his death, and the firſt day of the Week, which is our Chriſtian Sabbath? 1 Cor. 15.4. Joh. 20.1.

div.p: Qu. What is the Sixth Article?
Anſw. He aſcended into Heaven, And ſitteth on the Right Hand of God the Father Almighty.

row.cell: §. WHEN our Lord was riſen, Did He continue always on Earth in his bodily preſence? Joh. 16.16.
Did He not according to Prophecy Pſal. 64.18. Forty days after his Reſurrection, Acts 1.3. Aſcend up into Heaven in the ſight of his Diſciples? Acts 1.9— 11.
Was He not pleaſed to ſhew himſelf to ſome of his Diſciples after his aſcention? Acts 7.55. 1 Cor. 15.8
† Did He not Aſcend to prepare manſions for his people, Joh. 14.2. and to ſend his Spirit to prepare them for the enjoyment thereof? Joh. 16.7.
Are we to expect his bodily preſence any more on Earth, before the day of judgment? Acts 3.21.
§. BEING aſcended doth He not ſit at the Right Hand of God the Father Almighty? Mark 16.19.
Doth the Right Hand denote any bodily parts in God; or His ſitting any one particular geſture there? Acts 7.55.
Doth not ſitting down denote Reſt, and the Right Hand dignity and authority? Pſal. 44.3. 1 Kings 1.30.
* And did not Chriſt after all his ſorrows on Earth, reſt in the unſpeakable joy of his Father? Heb. 4.10.
* Hath He not the higheſt dignity and authority, Heb. 1.4. and 8.1. and ſhall He not have compleat victory over all his Enemies? Pſal, 110.1.

div.p: Qu. What is the Seventh Article?
Anſw. From thence He ſhall come to judge the Quick and the Dead?

row.cell: §. BEING thus exalted, Hath He for ever abandon'd this Earth and his people therein? Joh. 14.3.
Beſides his Spiritual preſence always with his Church, will He not come again in the clouds, as He was ſeen to go up? Acts 1.11.

Is not this Second coming, to judge the world in
righteouſneſs, and is not the day ſet and appointed for it? Acts 17.31.
Do we know the day and hour when this appointed judgment will be? Mat. 24.36.
§. WILL He Judge them already Dead, and thoſe that are found Quick or alive at his coming? Acts 10.42.
When all are gather'd before Him, will He not Separate between the Godly and the wicked and give to every Man according to his Works? Mat. 25.32. 2 Cor. 5.10.
† Will it not be a day of refreſhing to the people of God, Acts. 3.19. and exceeding terrible to the wicked? 2 Theſ. 1.7, 8, 9.
Shall any by power or policy be able to eſcape, or hide themſelves from the Judge? Rev. 6.15, 16.
And muſt not all abide in that Condition to which they are adjudg'd for ever and ever? Heb. 6.2.

div.p: Qu. What is the Eighth Article?
Anſw. I Believe in the Holy Ghoſt?

row.cell: §. IS not the Holy Ghoſt God, Acts 5.3, 4. Eternal, before the World, Gen. 1.2. Omnipreſent, Pſal. 139.7. and knowing all things? 1 Cor. 2.10.
Is not He a perſon, Acts 13.2. diſtinct from the Father and Son? Joh. 14.26.
Is not He the Spirit of the Father, Luk. 14.19. and of the Son, Gal. 4.6. as proceeding from them both?
Is He inferiour to the Father or Son in eſſence or nature, or with reſpect to the worſhip and glory which is due to God alone? Mat. 28.19. 1 Cor. 6.19.
§. IS He not Holy in himſelf, and alſo as the Authour of Holineſs and Sanctification in us? Rom. 1.4.
† Muſt we not then believe in Him as a ſanctifier by whom we may have an intereſt in what Chriſt has done and ſuffer'd?
Are any partakers of ſaving Benefits by Chriſt, to whom they are not effectually apply'd or communicated? Joh. 1.11, 12.
Can Parents or Miniſters apply them to your Heart, or any but the Holy Spirit? Tit. 3.5, 6.
Doth not the Spirit do this by working Faith in the Heart by the Miniſtry of the word? Joh. 6.44, 45.
Doth He not by the Law convince the Sinner, Joh. 16.8. and by the Goſpel ſubdue the will and perſwade it to yeild to our Lord Jeſus Chriſt? Ezek. 36.26, 27.
Can we then be ſav'd by Chriſt without effectual calling and Regeneration by the Holy Ghoſt? Joh. 3.5.

div.p: Qu. What is the Ninth Article?
Anſw. (I believe) the Holy Catholick Church, the Communion of Saints.

row.cell: §. HATH not God a Church called out of the world to be his peculiar people? 1 Pet. 2.9.
Are not believers a diſtinct Body or Society joyn'd to Chriſt by Faith, Eph. 5.23. and to each other by love? Col. 2.2.
Can this Church be built on any other Head or foundation, than our Lord Jeſus Chriſt? 1 Cor. 3.11.
Is not part of this Church Triumphant in Heaven, Heb. 12.23. and part Militant on Earth? Col. 1 24.
Is the Church known by external Splendour, Pomp, or Secular Grandeur? Acts 2.42.
§. IS not this Church Holy, 1 Cor. 3.17. the Saints above perfectly, and the effectually called really ſo?
Are not all the viſible Members thereof called to Holineſs, and Holy by profeſſion and obligation? 1 Theſ. 4.7.
§ IS not the Church Catholick or Univerſal conſiſting of all Believers, Jews and Gentiles, Bond and Free? Gal. 3.28.
Is the Church confin'd to any one place or Nation? Acts 1.8.
Shall the Gates of Hell ever prevail againſt it? Mat. 16.18.
† May any of the particular Societys (of which it doth conſiſt, Rev. 1.20.) claim the name, Authority and priviledges of the Catholick Church? Rom. 11.22.
§. AMONGST the many priviledges of the Church, Pſal. 87.3. is not this one, that there is the Communion of Saints?
* Have not Bel •• vers Union and Communion with Chriſt their Head, from whence they are called Saints? 1 Joh. 1.3.
Do they not Communicate by Faith their wants to him, 1 Pet. 5.7. and He by his Spirit Communicate his Merits and Grace to them? Iſa. 53.4. 1 Joh. 5.12.
And will he refuſe to ſuch, Communion with himſelf in Glory hereafter? Joh. 17.24.
* Have not the Saints alſo Communion one with another? 1 Joh. 1.7. 1 Cor. 12.26.
Can they Communicate Merits to each other? Mat. 25.8, 9.
* Have not the Saints above Communion with each other in the ſame Viſion, Employment and Glory? Mat. 8.11.
* Have not the Saints below Communion, in the ſame Gifts and Graces, Eph. 4.5. Heb. 3.13. in the ſame Sufferings, Heb. 13.3. and if need be, in their Worldly goods? Heb. 13.16.

div.p: Qu. What is the Tenth Article?
Anſw. The forgiveneſs of Sins.

row.cell: §. ARE there any Sins, Original or Actual, of Omiſſion or Commiſſion, of Thought, Word or Deed, that do not deſerve eternal Death? Rom. 6.23.
Yet are there any that are not Pardonable (the Sin againſt the Holy Ghoſt only excepted?) Mat. 12.31.
* Doth not forgiveneſs of Sins conſiſt in releaſing the Sinner from Guilt and Condemnation? Pſal. 32.1, 2.
Can any but God (who is the party offended) forgive Sins to Men? Pſal 51.4. Mark 2.7.
Yet muſt not all forgive injuries done to themſelves, Mat. 18.21. and Miniſters Pronounce forgiveneſe in Chriſt's name to the Penitent? Mat. 18.18. 2 Cor. 2.7, 10.
* Is there any forgiveneſs but only through Chriſt, and on the account of his Satisfaction? Col. 1.14.
* Doth the Satisfaction of Chriſt make forgiveneſs of Sins to be leſs Free and Gracious? Eph. 1.7.
* Have any the actual forgiveneſs of their Sins before they Repent and Believe? Joh. 3.18.
† Muſt you not then have a deep ſenſe of your Sins, Acts 2.38. Confeſs them to God, Pſal. 32.5. with a ſincere Reſolution of forſaking them? Pro. 28.13.
Muſt you not earneſtly make Supplication for Pardon, with a Fiducial truſt in the mercy of God, through the Merits and Righteouſneſs of Chriſt alone? Acts 10.43.

div.p: Qu. What is the Eleventh Article?
Anſw. The Reſurrection of the Body.

row.cell: §. DID not death come in by Sin, as the Sentence of the Law for the Tranſgreſſion of it? Rom. 5.12.
* Can any of our Members, when turn'd to duſt and ſcatter'd, be hid from God's all-ſeeing Eye? Pſal. 137.15, 16.
Is it above the Almighty power that made the Body at firſt of duſt, to raiſe it out of it again? Mark 12.24.
* And as He is able to raiſe the Dead, ſo are we to believe that He will do it? Joh. 5.28, 29.
Though all ſhall be rais'd, the juſt and the unjuſt, Acts 24.15. yet is not the Reſurrection the ſpecial Priviledge of Believers? Luk. 14.14.
* Shall the Wicked riſe by vertue of an Union with Chriſt by his Spirit, as the Godly ſhall? Rom. 8.11.
* And will there not be a vaſt difference between them in the ends for which they ariſe? Dan. 12.2.
Is it not agreeable to Divine Juſtice, that the ſame Bodies for ſubſtance, which we had here, ſhould be raiſed then? 1 Cor. 15.38. 2 Cor. 5.10.
But will they be raiſed to the ſame dying and mortal State they were in before? 1 Cor. 15.53.
Will not the Bodies of the Saints be exceeding Glorious, of which the Reſurrection of Chriſt is both an aſſurance and a Pattern? 1 Cor. 15.20, 43, 44.
† And ſhall not they who are found alive at the coming of Chriſt be alſo chang'd? 1 Cor. 15.51, 52.

div.p: Qu. What is the Twelfth Article?
Anſw. The life Everlaſting.

row.cell: §. SHALL not Believers have a Life of Glory and happineſs in the World to come? Pſal. 16.11.

* Do their Souls then ſleep with their Bodies in the
Grave, or go to Purgatory? Rev. 14.13.
Are we able to expreſs the Glory of that State, which God has prepared, 1 Cor. 2.9. and they enter into immediately after Death? Phil. 1.23.
Shall they not enjoy a Beatifical viſion and enjoyment of God, with Saints and Angels, in the higheſt employment of Praiſe, without Sin or Suffering? Pſal. 17.15.
* and ſhall not their Bodies alſo partake of this Life of Glory at laſt? 1 Cor. 15.43.
§. IS it not an everlaſting Life in oppoſition to this fading Life on Earth? 1 Theſ. 4.17.
Will the Life above be Subject to decays, and changes, and interruptions in the happineſs of it? 1 Pet. 1.4.
Will they be in danger of forfeiting this happineſs, or any Enemy be admitted to diſpoſſeſs them of it? Rev. 3.12.
† Is there not an everlaſting Death contrary to this everlaſting Life? Rom. 6.23.
Is this for the Wicked to have their beings taken away, and to remain no more? Rev. 21.8.
Is it not to be baniſhed from the preſence of God and to undergo the Torments of Hell for ever? 2 Theſ. 1.9. Mat. 25.46.
† Do we not ſay Amen to teſtifie our firm Belief of theſe Articles? Rev. 22.20, 21.

p.hi: What doſt thou chiefly learn in theſe Articles of thy Belief.

div.p: Firſt, I learn to believe in God the Father who hath made me, and all the World.
Secondly, in God the Son, who hath redeemed me, and all mankind.
Thirdly, in God the Holy Ghoſt, who ſanctifieth me, and all the Elect people of God.

row.cell: §. IS there not manifeſted a Divine order in the Works of the Bleſſed Trinity towards Men?
When Creation is aſcribed to the Father, doth it mean that it was not the Work of the Son and Holy Ghoſt? Joh. 1.3. Gen. 1.2.

Is it not that the Father did Create all things by the
Son, Heb. 1.2. and by the power of his Holy Spirit? Job 26.13.
And ſhould not we and all the World Worſhip and adore the Lord our maker? Rev. 4.11.
§. IS not the Work of Redemption peculiarly aſcribed to God the Son? 1 Tim. 2.5, 6.
Were we not by Sin bound over to the Wrath of God, and in ſlavery to Sin and Satan? Gal. 3.10. 2 Tim. 2.26.
* Could any meaner Price than his bloud ſatisfy Gods juſtice for our Redemption? 1 Pet 1.18.
* Could any leſs power than of his Spirit reſcue our Souls from the bondage of the Devil? Luk. 11.22.
§. DO you mean by his redeeming all mankind that all Men have equal benefit in the Price that He laid down? Mat. 20.28.
* Yet is not the Price ſufficient for all as being the bloud of Him, that was truly God? Acts 20.28.
* Have not all Men indifferently a reprieve granted them and many Temporal favours by means of Chriſt's Death? 1 Tim. 4.10.
* Is it a ſmall matter that hereby there are offers of Pardon and Salvation to every Creature whereever the Goſpel comes? Mark 16.15.
* Is He not indeed a ranſom for all, being for Jews and Gentiles, into which two parts all mankind are divided? Heb. 2.9. 1 Joh. 2.2.
* And may not all mankind mean a great many out of every Nation and Language? Joh. 12.32. Rev. 7.9.
† Should they then live as others do, who are in eſpecial manner the redeemed of the Lord? 1 Cor. 6.20.
§. IS not the work of Sanctification peculiarly aſcribed to the Holy Ghoſt. 1 Pet. 1.2.
* Are not all that are Baptized Sanctify'd, or ſet apart for a Holy uſe? 1 Cor. 7.14.
And is not our Office and Miniſtry, by which you were ſo dedicated, from the Holy Spirit? 1 Cor. 12.11, 13.
† Dare you then forget your Baptiſmal Sanctification, 2 Pet. 1.9. or tread under Foot the bloud of the Covenant by which you were Sanctify'd? Heb. 10.29.

* Is this dedication enough without an inward Sanctification
by the gracious operation of the Holy Ghoſt, in the renewing and converting the Soul? 1 Cor. 6.11.
§. IS there not a certain number known to the Lord, 2 Tim. 2.19. whom the Father hath choſen to Sanctification and Holyneſs? 2 Theſ. 2.13.
Is there any way for us to know our Election, but by Sanctification and effectual calling? 1 Theſ. 1.4, 5.

p.hi: You ſaid that your Bodfathers and Godmothers did promiſe for you, that you ſhould keep God's Commandments. Tell me how many they be?
The ſame which God ſpake in the Twentieth Chapter of Exodus, ſaying, I am the Lord thy God which brought thee out of the Land of Egypt, out of the Houſe of Bondage.

div.p: I. Thou ſhalt have none other Gods, but me.

II. Thou ſhalt not make to thy ſelf any graven Image, nor the likeneſs of any thing that is in Heaven above, or in the Earth beneath, or in the mater under the Earth. Thou ſhalt not bow down to them, nor Worſhip them. For I the Lord thy God am a jealous God, and viſit the Sins of the Fathers upon the Children, unto the third and fourth Generation of them that hate me, and ſhew mercy unto Thouſands in them that love me and keep my Commandments.
III. Thou ſhalt not take the Name of the Lord thy God in vain: for the Lord will not hold him guiltleſs that taketh his name in vain.

IV. Remember that thou keep Holy the Sabbath day. Sir days ſhalt thou labour, and do all that thou haſt to do: out the Seventh day is the Sabbath of the Lord thy God. In it thou ſhalt do no manner of work, Thou, and thy Son, and thy Daughter, thy Man-ſervant, and thy Maid-ſervant, thy Cattle, and the Stranger that is within thy ſtates. For in Six days the Lord made Heaven and Earth, the Sea and all that in them is, and reſted the Seventh day; wherefore the Lord
bleſſed the ( Heb. Sabbath.) Seventh day, and hallowed it.
V. Honour thy Father and thy Mother, that thy days may be long in the Land, which the Lord thy God giveth thee.
VI. Thou ſhalt do no Murther.
VII. Thou ſhalt not commit Adultery.
VIII. Thou ſhalt not Steal.
IX. Thou ſhalt not bear falſe witneſs againſt thy Neighbour.
X. Thou ſhalt not covet thy Neighbours Houſe, thou ſhalt not covet thy Neighbours Wife, nor his Servant, nor his Maid, nor his Oxe, nor his Aſs, nor any thing that is his.

row.cell: §. IS not the Moral Law (as diſtinct from the Judicial and Ceremonial Law) ſum'd up in theſe Ten Commandments? Deut. 10.4.
Were they not ſpoken by the voice of God with much Terrour and Majeſty on Mount Sinai, and written on two Tables of Stone? Deut. 5.4, 22.
§. ARE not Unbelievers under the Curſe of the Law? Gal. 3.10.
And when Believers are delivered from the Curſe, is the Law made void and of none effect to them? Rom. 3.31.
* Have they not by the Law, the knowledge of Sin, Rom. 7.7. and are they not driven thereby to Chriſt? Gal. 3.24.
* Do they not delight in the Law and take it as a bleſſed Rule for them to walk by? Rom. 7.22.
Gan He be a true Believer that doth not acknowledge all the Commandments to be Holy, juſt and good? Rom. 7.12.
Are not the Commandments Spiritual, reaching the Heart, Rom. 7.14. and forbidding all degrees of Sin with the occaſions of them? Pſal. 119.96.
† Do you think it enough then, that you have learnt theſe words, without being taught the meaning of them?

div.p: Qu. What is the Preface to theſe Commandments?
Anſw. I am the Lord thy God, &c.

row.cell: §. IS it not ſufficient Reaſon to keep his Commandments, that He is the Soveraign Lord, Author of our beings, and diſpoſer of our Lives? Acts 17.24, 28. Levit. 22.31.
§. IS not his ſpecial relation to his people, as their God in Covenant, a further Reaſon of Obedience? Levit. 20.26.
Are believing Gentiles excluded from the Covenant Intereſt in Him, that the Jews had of old? Rom. 3.29.
§. DID not God wonderfully by the hand of Moſes redeem the Children of Iſrael out of Egyptian bondage? Exod. 12.41.
* And is it a leſs Mercy to be delivered from the bondage of Antichriſt (miſtically called Egypt? Rev. 11.8).
* Is not God's redeeming us from the Spiritual bondage of Sin and Satan, a further Obligation upon us to obey him? Luk. 1.74, 75.

div.p: Qu. Which is the Firſt Commandment?
Anſw. Thou ſhalt have no other Gods ‖ but me. ‖ Heb. before me.

row.cell: §. DOTH not this forbid the denying of the being of God, or any of his Divine attributes? Pſal. 14.1. and 10.11.
* Doth it not forbid having many Gods, or any other ſave the Lord? Gal. 4.8. 1 Cor. 10 5, 6.
May we uſe Divination, or conſult with thoſe that do? Deut. 18.10, 11.
* May we worſhip any Creature together with the true God? Zeph. 1.5. Rom. 1.25.
Is the invocation of Saints and Angels then to be allowed in the Church? Rom. 10.14.
* Doth it not forbid all falſe opinions of God, particularly in denying the Trinity or perſons of the Son and Spirit? Rom. 1.21, 22.
* May we truſt in, love or fear any Creature more than God? Jer. 17.5. 2 Tim. 3.4.
Do not men thus make riches, pleaſures and relations their God; yea, by Pride and vain Glory make Gods of themſelves? Phil. 3.19. Acts 12.23.
* Doth it not condemn all neglect of God and his worſhip when men live as without God in the world? Eph. 2.12.
Is not all that men do againſt this Commandment done before him: and doth He mark and deteſt the Sin of Idolatry? Pſal. 44.20, 21.
§. IS it enough to have no other Gods if we alſo do not know and own the true God? 1 Chron. 28.9.
* Muſt we not avouch the Lord to be our God, Deut. 26.17, 18. and Worſhip Him with a Spiritual Worſhip, Suited his nature? Joh. 4.24.
* Can we Worſhip him aright without fear and reverence, humility and ſelf-abaſement? Heb. 12.28. Job 42.5, 6.
Can it be done, without Faith in God through Chriſt, thankfulneſs, love and delight? Pſal. 29.2.
† Will God accept of outward acts of Worſhip, without a Spiritual Principle and Spiritual ends and deſigns? Hoſ. 8.13.

div.p: Qu. What is the Second Commandment?
Anſw. Thou ſhalt not make unto thy Self any Graven Image, &c.

row.cell: §. BESIDES the Spiritual Worſhip, is there not alſo outward Worſhip in kneeling and bowing down the Body? 1 Cor. 6.20.
May we pay this outward worſhip to Images of whatſoever kind? Levit. 26.1.
* Is it not impoſſible as well as unlawful, to make an Image of God, of the Trinity, or of any of the Divine perſons? Deut. 4.15, 16. Iſa. 40.18.
Is it unlawful to make an Image of Creatures for Civil and Hiſtorical uſes? Mat. 22.20, 21.
* But is it not the higheſt affront to the Divine Majeſty to compare Him to Creatures? Rom. 1.21 —26.
* May we bring any ſuch Image into the Church, as an Object or means of Worſhip? Pſal. 115.4, 5.
* May we worſhip God by Images, as ſuppoſing ſome Divine vertue to be lodg'd in them? Exod. 32.4, 5.
* May we pretend to worſhip God in our Hearts, and bow down to an Image with our Bodyes? Dan. 3.18.
* Can we be preſent at Image worſhip, without danger of Sin, and ſcandal? 1 Cor. 8.10.
Is not the Church of Rome guilty of Idolatry in worſhipping Images, and of Sacriledge in leaving out the Second Commandment?
* May we worſhip God in a way of our own or other Mens deviſing? Mat. 15.2, 8, 9.
Yet hath not God allowed the Governours of his Church to order the external Circumſtances of his Worſhip, ſo that nothing be contrary to his own word? 1 Cor. 11.4, 5.
And may not ſuch Circumſtances (though not particularly Commanded by God) come under the general Commands of decency, edification, concord, and obedience to Magiſtrates? Rom. 14.19. 1 Cor. 14.40.
But may any Men under whatever pretence add to, alter, or take away from the Subſtance of Gods worſhip? Deut. 12.32. Col. 2.23.
* May we have Carnal thoughts of God or groſs conceits of him in our minds? Ezek. 14.3, 4.
§. IF we muſt not worſhip him by Images; muſt not we do it in his own way, according to his word? Mat. 28.20.
* Hath He not appointed his Goſpel Ordinances of Prayer, reading, hearing, Singing, and the uſe of his Sacraments?
* Is it enough to obſerve the matter of Ordinances without the Inſtituted manner or Order? 1 Chron. 15.13.
May we then caſt off any of his Ordinances or account them unprofitable and vain? Mala. 3.14.
§. IS not his being the Lord our God the Lawgiver of his Church the reaſon of obedience to his Inſtitutions? Jam. 4.12.
* Is not his Zeal for his Glory, a further reaſon againſt all falſe Worſhip, or neglect of the true? Exod. 34.14.
Doth He not mark how we worſhip, and ſeverely puniſh them that break this Commandment? Ezek. 16.38.
And though they pretend love, doth not God account of Idolaters as of Haters of him, becauſe they hate his People and ways? 2 Chron. 19.2.
§. IF the Children of ſuch wicked Men prove Godly, ſhall they dye for their Fathers Sins? Ezek. 18.14, 17.
But is it unjuſt with God, when the Children follow their Fathers Steps, to perſue them with Judgments for their Sins through divers Generations? Ezekiel 18.25.
§. DOTH not his Mercy far exceed his ſeverity when extended to thoſe that Worſhip him aright? Deut. 5.29.

div.p: Qu. What is the Third Commandment?
Anſw. Thou ſhalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain, &c.

row.cell: §. IS not the name of God, that by which He is made known, as his Titles, attributes, ordinances and word?
* Doth not this forbid the blaſpheming Gods name, and all curſing our Selves or others? Levit. 24.11, 14.
* May we uſe any of the Titles of God or Chriſt careleſly or in our Common Diſcourſe? Phil. 2.10. Pſal. 139.20.
* Is not all falſe Swearing or Perjury a tremendous prophanation of Gods name? Levit. 19.12.
* May we violate our Lawful Oaths; though made to our dammage, Pſal. 15.4. or break our Faith, though ſworn to Infidels and Heriticks? Joſh. 9.18, 19.
* Is not raſh, paſſionate, and vain Swearing the general abuſe of Gods name at this day? Jer. 5.12.
May we uſe Phariſaical Oaths, by Creatures, Mat. 5.34-36. or Popiſh Oaths, by Mary, the Maſs, &c. Jer. 5.7.
May we uſe unneceſſary aſſeverations or ridiculous Oaths, in new Coyn'd words? Mat. 5.37.
* Are we not forbidden to abuſe his Grace and Patience, Rom. 2.4. or by any unworthy carriage to expoſe his name to reproach? Jer. 7.9, 10. Rom. 2.24.
* May we uſe any Scripture, Matter or Phraſe for jeſting and Sport? 2 Pet. 3.4.
* May we uſe vain repetitions, Mat. 6.7. or call on his name for an Hypocritical pretence? Luk. 20.47.
* Is not all careleſs Lip-worſhip without the Heart a Prophaning the name of God? Ezek. 33.31.
§. DO not the prophaners of Gods name ſometimes eſcape the Judgment of men? 1 Sam. 3.13.
* But if God hold them guilty, and take the matter into his hand, can they then eſcape? 1 Sam. 2.25.

* Are they not ſometimes plagu'd in this World by the Curſe of God, Zech. 5.4. Deut. 28.58, 59. and is not a more dreadful Judgment reſerved for them in the other? Mala •
3.5.
§. IS all Swearing, or taking an Oath, forbidden by this Commandment? Deut. 6.13. Heb. 6.16.
* Is not right Swearing a part of Goſpel Worſhip, Iſa. 45.23. and muſt we not do it (when called) in Truth, Judgment and Righteouſneſs? Jer. 4.2.
* Muſt we not Reverence his name in his Worſhip, Pſal. 111.9. call upon his name and bleſs it? Job 1.21.
* Muſt we not Honour his name in our Actions, and take heed that we deny it not before men? Rev. 2.13.

div.p: Qu. Which is the Fourth Commandment?
Anſw. Remember that thou keep Holy the Sabbath day, &c.

row.cell: §. SEEING nature teacheth us there muſt be a time fixt for Gods worſhip, is it fit that it ſhould be left to men to determine it?
Hath not God fix't a Seventh part of time, and made the obſerving it part of his Moral Law that ſhall not paſs away? Mat. 5.18.
Was not the Sabbath ordain'd in Paradice, Gen. 2.2, 3. obſerv'd before the Ceremonial Law, Exod. 16.25. and ordered to continue in Goſpel times? Iſa. 56.1, 2.
* But is it neceſſary to obſerve the ſame day of the Week, which the Jews obſerved before the Reſurrection of Chriſt? Mark. 2.28. Ezek. 43.27.
Is not the firſt day of the week on which He aroſe called the Lords day, Rev. 1.10. and mention'd as the known time for Worſhip in the Churches? 1 Cor. 16.1, 2.
And have we not the conſtant Practice of the Church for this change, from the Apoſtles time to this day? Acts 2.1. and 20.6, 7.
§. ARE we leſs oblig'd to Goſpel Ordinances on the Lords day than the Jews were to their legal obſervances on their Sabbath? Levit. 23.3.
* Should we not remember the Holy Sabbath to prepare for it before it comes? Luk. 23.54. Iſa. 66.23.
* Are we not to obſerve on the Sabbath a Reſt from all manner of common work and buſineſs? Neh. 13.15.
But muſt we neglect works of Piety (though done with bodily labour,) Mat. 12.5. or works of neceſſity and mercy? Luk. 14.5.
May we think and talk of the worldly buſineſs that we abſtain from doing, Ezek. 33.31, 32, or run to Recreations and Secular Pleaſures? Iſa. 58.13.
* Muſt it not be a Holy Reſt, taken up in obſerving all duties of Divine Worſhip? Acts 20.7.
Muſt we not riſe Early, Pſal. 92.2. and perſiſt in the duties of the day without wearineſs or grudging? Amos. 8.5.
* Can we keep a Sabbath aright if we wilfully neglect or forſake the Publick Aſſemblies? Heb. 10.2 • .
Yet when they are over, is not the reſt of the day to be ſpent in repetition of what we have heard, Holy conference, and meditation? Luk. 24.14, 17.
§. MAY Maſters of Families (into whoſe hands this Commandment is put, Exod. 20.10.) ſuffer any under their charge to Prophane the Sabbath?
And muſt not Magiſtrates enjoyn the obſervation of the Sabbath, and puniſh the neglect? Neh. 13.17, 22.
Yet if they neglect it, will God ſuffer Sabbath breakers to go unpuniſht? Jer. 17.27.
† And are days of Faſting and Thankſgiving, Lawfully appointed, to be Religiouſly obſerv'd? Eſth. 4.16. and 9.21.
§. DARE you rob God of what He claims an Intereſt in, when He hath allowed you Six days for your own Work?
Hath not God given his own Example by reſting Himſelf on the Seventh day, and bleſſing and hallowing the Sabbath? Gen. 2.3.

† Doth not the keeping the Sabbath tend highly to the Honour or God, Iſa. 58.13. and the preſerving
his Worſhip in the World? Ezek. 20.12.
Can we expect a bleſſing on our Week-days Labour, if we prophane the Sabbath? Iſa. 56.2.
Yet is it enough to Worſhip God on the Lords day, if we neglect his Worſhip on other days? Pſal. 145.2.

div.p: Qu. Which is the Fifth Commandment?
Anſw. Honour thy Father and thy Mother, &c.

row.cell: §. DOTH not this Commandment enjoyn the mutual duties of Superiours and Inferiours to each other in every Relation?
(1.) Muſt not Children honour their natural Parents, the Authors of their being under God? Eph. 6.2.
* If Parents are Aged, Poor or Weak, may Children deſpiſe them, in Heart or Carriage? Pro. 23.22.
* Muſt they not fear to offend them, Levit. 19.3. and Submit to their reproofs and corrections? Heb. 12.9.
* Muſt they not obey their Commands in all Lawful things, though they ſeem harſh and ſevere? Col. 3.20.
* May they murmur at their Proviſion or reject their advice in Marriage or matters of moment? Gen. 21.21. and 26.24.
* Muſt they not follow their Godly Inſtructions and examples, Pro. 4.1, 3. and endeavour to be a Comfort to them in their old Age? Prov. 10.1. and 25.20.
* May they divulge their infirmities, waſt their eſtates, Prov. 19.26. or reflect diſhonour upon them by their wicked Lives? Prov. 29.15.
* Muſt they not endeavour to requite their Parent • in praying for them, and maintaining them if they be in want? 1 Tim. 5.4.
And muſt not Children by Adoption and affinity honour their Parents? Eſth. 2.7, 20. Ruth. 3.1, 5.
§. DO not Parents owe to their Children tender, ſincere and conſtant Love? Col. 3.21.
May they under pretence of loving them, loſe their juſt Authority over them?. Gen. 18.19.
* Having ſeriouſly devoted them to God, muſt they not diligently teach and inſtruct them? Deut. 6.6-8.
* May they ſuffer them to live in idleneſs, without a Lawful Calling and honeſt labour? Mat. 21.28.

* Muſt they not mark their Inclinations and Company,
reprove them for their faults, and (in caſe of ſin and ſtubbornneſs) correct them? Prov. 29.15, 17. and 23.13, 14.
But may they by reproachful Language and wicked Commands, provoke them to wrath and diſcourage them? Eph. 6.4.
* Muſt they not ſet them a good example, and dayly pray for a bleſſing upon them? Job 1.5.
(2.) Muſt not Servants honour their Maſters, 1 Tim. 6.1. and obey their juſt Commands? 1 Pet. 2.18.
* May they by ſtubborn ſilence, private mutterings, or croſs anſwers, provoke their Maſters? Tit. 2.9.
May they waſt their Maſters Goods, Tit. 2.9. or neglect his buſineſs, when his Eye is off? Col. 3.22, 23.
* Muſt they not bleſs God for Godly Maſters, pray for them, Gen. 24.12. and ſubmit to Inſtructions and Reproofs?
§. SHOULD Maſters, that would mind their Duty be indifferent or careleſs about what Servants they take into their Houſes? Pſal. 101.6, 7.
* May they rule over them with rigour, as if they were Slaves or Beaſts, Levit. 25.46. without regard to the health of their Bodies, Mat 8.5, 6. or good of their Souls? Gen. 18.19.
* Muſt they not give them what is juſt and equal, as to Inſtruction, Proviſion, Work and Wages? Prov. 31.15. Jam. 5.4.
(3.) Is not the duty of Wives Sum'd up in a reverend and quiet Subjection, and the duty of Husbands in an entire and intenſe love? Eph. 5.24, 25.
(4.) Are not Magiſtrates our civil Parents, Iſa. 49.23. and muſt we not Honour and Reverence them? 1 Pet. 2.17.
* May we revile our Rulers, or uſe any indecent words concerning them? Eccl. 10.20. Acts 23.5.
* Muſt we not by all juſt means defend their perſons, Rom. 13.1, 2. pay them Taxes, Mat. 22.21. and be Subject to their lawful Commands? Tit. 3.1.
§. MAY Magiſtrates forget by whom they Reign, or caſt off the fear of God in their Covernment? 2 Sam. 23.3.
(5.) Are not Miniſters our Eccleſiaſtical Parents, 2 Kings 2.12. whom we muſt know, Honour and eſteem? 1 Theſ. 5.12, 13.
* May we defraud them of their maintenance, 1 Tim. 5.17. 1 Cor. 9.11. or deſpiſe their Godly Diſciplines? Heb. 13.17.
* Muſt we not receive their Holy Doctrines as the word of God, 1 Theſ. 2.13. and conſult with them in difficult Caſes? Mala. 2.7.
§. MUST Not Miniſters be Holy in their Carriage, apt to teach, able to convince gain-ſayers and to Comfort the afflicted? Tit. 1.9.
(6.) May we neglect a ſuitable reſpect and Honour to any others that are above us, in Age, Gifts, or quality? Levit. 19.32.
§. IS not this the firſt Commandment with Promiſe, Eph. 6.2, 3. becauſe Obedience thereunto tends to proſperity and the lengthening out of our days? Deut. 5.16.
† Doth not this ſhew us that Honouring our Parents is well-pleaſing to God, Col. 3.20. and that Godlineſs hath the promiſes of this Life as well as that to come? 1 Tim. 4.8.
But if Children are Hypocritically Obedient, hath He Promiſed not to cut them off for their other ſins?
Yea if Children be Godly and Dutiful for Chriſt's ſake, is this Promiſe abſolute without any Condition? 1 Kings 14.13.
May He not take them away from the evils of this Life, and give them the bleſſing of eternal Life? Iſa. 57.1, 2.
† Can they that perſiſt in diſobedience to their Parents eſcape the dreadful Curſe pronounc'd on the breakers of this Commandment? Deut. 27.16. Pro. 30.17.

div.p: Qu. Which is the Sixth Commandment?
Anſw. Thou ſhalt not Kill. Or, Thou ſhalt do no Murder.

row.cell: §. DOTH not this forbid the taking away unjuſtly the life of Man, who was made after the Image of God? Gen. 9.3, 6.
Is it Murder or unlawful for the Magiſtrate to take away the lives of Criminals by Publick Juſtice? Num. 35.31.
Is it Murder to ſhed Bloud in a Lawful War, Jer. 48.10. or to kill a Man in our neceſſary ſelf-defence? Exod. 22.2, 3.
* Is it not Murder to kill a Man in a Paſſion, Exod. 21.23. and yet greater if done with malice and fixed hatred? Gen. 4.8.
* Is not the ſin yet greater if done by force and violence in an open aſſault, Num. 35.16. or by Witchcraft and help of the Devil? Exod. 22.18.
Doth blind Zeal excuſe the Murderer, if He ſhould think He ought to do it? Joh. 16.2.
Are Duels Lawful, or can any pretence of Gallantry, or injuries receiv'd, excuſe them? Rom. 12.19.
* Doth it not forbid all hurting and wounding our Neighbours Bodies, Exod. 21.24, 25. and all occaſions of Bloud-ſhed? Deut. 22.8.
* May we by Contrivance, hiring, or falſe Accuſation conſent or be acceſſary to Murder? Prov. 1.10-12.
* Is not Self-murder a moſt unnatural Sin and without poſſibility of Repentance? Mat. 27.5.
Doth not all Murder make Men odious to God, and like the Devil, who was a Murderer from the beginning? Joh. 8.44.
* Are not all rayling and reviling Words, and all malice and unjuſt anger in the Heart, as murder in Gods account? 1 Joh. 3.15. Mat. 5.21, 22.
§. IS it ſufficient that we do not ſtrike or wound our Neighbour, if we uſe no due care to preſerve his Life? Luk. 10.33.—36.
* Muſt we not ſuccour the diſtreſſed, protect the innocent and deliver them from wrongs? Job 29.13.
* May we needleſly hazard our own lives, Mat. 10.23. or neglect the moderate uſe of Food, Phyſick, Labour, or what may tend to the Health of our Bodies? 1 Tim. 5.23.

div.p: Qu. What is the Seventh Commandment?
Anſw. Thou ſhalt not Commit Adultery.

row.cell: §. MAY any forbid Marriage which God has ordain'd for mutual Society, the avoiding Fornication, and the increaſe of the Church? Heb. 13.4. 1 Tim. 4.3.
* Is it Lawful for any to have more Wives than one, Mala. 2.15. or to put away his Wife, ſaving for the cauſe of Fornication? Mat. 19.9.
* Is it Lawful to contract Marriage with thoſe that are near of Kin within the degrees mentioned in the Law? Levit. 18. 1 Cor. 5.1.
Is it not a ſhame to mention the ſecret Luſts of uncleanneſs whereby ſinners defile their own and others bodies, in a ſingle or married State? Eph. 5.12.
* Is not Adultery or the breach of the marriage Covenant, Mala. 2.14. the direct ſin againſt this Commandment?
* Y • t doth it excuſe the uncleanneſs, called Fornication, that it is committed by ſingle perſons, 1 Cor. 6.9, 18. or with a purpoſe and promiſe of marriage afterwards? Gen. 34.31.
Do not theſe ſins bring deſtruction on Nations and Families, and ruin on the Eſtate and reputation of the ſinner? Prov. 6.26, 33.
Do they not deſtroy the health and lives, Prov. 5.8, 11, and more eſpecially the Souls of the guilty? 1 Pet. 2.11.
Are they uſually committed by any but who are firſt given up by God and abhorred by him? Prov. 22.14. Rom. 1.24.
Are there many Inſtances of thoſe that have return'd and repented after the commiting of ſuch ſins? Prov. 2.18, 19.
Do they not expoſe men to Excommunication from the Church and to Damnation in Hell? 1 Cor. 5.11. and 6.9, 10.
* Doth not this Law extend to the forbidding the Luſtings of the Heart, Mat. 5.28. the uncleanneſs of the Tongue, Eph. 4.29. and the adultery of the Eye? 2 Pet. 2.14. Prov. 6.25.
May we read wanton Books, wear immodeſt Attire, Prov 7.10. live in idleneſs, 2 Sam. 11.2. or have familiar converſe with unchaſt perſons? Prov. 5.8.
Are not Gluttony and Drunkenneſs the great incentives to the Luſts of uncleanneſs? Jer. 5.7. Prov. 23.31-33.
§. MUST we not take great care to preſerve our own and others Chaſtity, in heart, ſpeech, and behaviour? 1 Theſ. 4.4. 1 Tim. 2.9.
Can this be done without watching over our Senſes, Job 31.1. and watching againſt Temptations, 1 Pet. 5.8. eſpecially in a time of Youth? 2 Tim. 2.22.

div.p: Qu. Which is the Eighth Commandment?
Anſw. Thou ſhalt not Steal.

row.cell: §. HATH God left all things in Common for every one that is ſtrongeſt or moſt crafty to ſeize on what He can get? Habak. 2.8.
* Is it not theft to take away anothers Goods unjuſtly, Joh. 12.6. though never ſo ſecretly? Joſh. 7.21.
* May we be Confederates with Thieves, Prov. 1.10.—14, pertake of, or receive what they have Stollen, or conceal their Perſons or Goods? Prov. 29.24.
* Is it not aggravated by the violence that is uſed in Robbery and Piracy, Judg. 9.25. or by Stealing things Dedicated to God, called Sacriledge? Rom. 2.22.
* May men waſt Riotouſly their own Eſtates, and thereby Rob themſelves and their Families? Prov. 21.17.
Is not Theft contrary to the Light of Nature as well as the Law of Chriſt, and doth it not expoſe the Guilty to a ſevere Condemnation? 1 Cor. 6.10.
* May we uſe any unlawful calling, 2 Pet. 2.15. or any Guile or defrauding, though in a lawful calling? Mark. 10.19. 1 Theſ. 4.6.
* May we put off bad or falſe Wares and Mony for good, or uſe Falſe Weights and Meaſures? Amos. 8.5, 6. Prov. 11.1.
* May we ſet unconſcionable Prices on our Goods, Levit. 25.14, 16. or Work upon the ignorance or neceſſities of them we deal with? Prov. 22.22, 23.
* May we buy of thoſe that we vehemently ſuſpect have no right to Sell, or immoderately praiſe our own, or diſpraiſe anothers Goods? Prov. 20.14.
* Is it not grievous Theft to be falſe in Places or matters of Truſt, eſpecially in the Wills of the Dead? Gal. 3.15.

* May we refuſe to pay juſt Debts, if we are able, Rom. 13.8. or borrow without being likely to pay,
unleſs we lay open our Caſe? Pſal. 37.21.
* May we treſpaſs upon the Lands of others, Prov. 22.28. or with-hold corn to advance the Price in a time of ſcarcity? Prov. 11.26.
* May we keep Loſt Goods which we have found, without a ſu • table diligence to enquire out the Owner? Deut. 22.2, 3.
§. MUST we then in a Lawful uſe of ſome good C • lling caſt our care upon the Lord and eat our own bread? Eph. 4.28. 2 Theſ. 3.11, 12.
* Muſt we not do to others as we would be done by, Mat. 7.12. Give to all their due, Rom. 13.7. and Linder what we can any damage from befalling our Neighbours Eſtate? Deut. 22.1.
Can there be true Repentance for ſins of injuſtice, without reſtoring what we have defrauded, to the utmoſt of our power? Mic. 6.10, 11. Luk. 19.8.
* Muſt we not give largely of our well-gotten Goods to the Poor, according to their neceſſity, eſpecially to the Godly and them that ſuffer for Chriſts ſake? 2 Cor. 8.2.

div.p: Qu. Which is the Ninth Commandment?
Anſw. Thou ſhalt not bear falſe Witneſs, &c.

row.cell: §. DOTH not this in the Letter forbid the affirming any thing falſely againſt another in Courts of Judicature? Acts 6.11, 13. and 24.9.
* May we therefore for fear, favour, or malice, conceal the truth, Acts 24.19, 20. or knowingly change or wreſt the words of another? Mar. 26.60, 61.
* May we ſuborn falſe Witneſſes, 1 Kings 21.9, 10. o • may Judges and Juries Wittingly admit of them, to Juſtify the Wicked or condemn the Righteous? Deut. 1. • 7.
* And though it be in common converſe, may we raiſe falſe Reports, Neh. 6.6, 8. or lightly take them up and ſpread them? Pſal. 15.3.
* May we put the worſt Conſtructions on our Neighbours words and actions, 1 Sam. 22.9, 10. or carry about Tales openly or ſecretly to diſgrace him? Levit. 19.16.
Is not all falſe Witneſſing and Slandering injurious to Men and hateful to God? Prov. 6.19, 20. and 19.5.
* Doth not this Condemn all Lying, as highly provoking to God, contrary to all Society amongſt men, and making men like the Devil the Father of it? Prov. 6.16, 17. Joh. 8.44.
Is it Lawful to Lye, under pretence of Gods Glory, the preſervation of Religion, Joh. 13.7. Rom. 3.7, 8. or for any Worldly gain whatſoever? Prov. 21.6.
And if we may not Lye for our own or others Profit, may we for their Sport or Pleaſure? Prov. 26.18, 19.
May we uſe Artificial modes of Lying, by Equivocations and Mental Reſervations? Acts 5.8.
Yet the more pernicious and hurtful any Lye is to our Neighbour, is it not ſo much the more abominable? Pſal. 52.4.
§. MUST not all behave themſelves in Courts of Judicature, as under the awe of the peculiar preſence and Oath of God? Pſal. 82.1, 2.
* Muſt we not in our whole Converſation Love the Truth, and (when we are called to ſpeak) utter it? Eph. 4.25.
May we Promiſe any thing that we intend not to perform, or neglect the performance, if it be Lawful?
* Muſt we not rejoyce in the good Name of our Neighbour, and be grieved when they deſerve or receive diſgrace? 1 Cor. 12.26.
Muſt we not Charitably think the beſt, 1 Cor. 13.5. and cover th • ir Faults, 1 Pet. 4.8. and in what we can ſpeak well of them? 1 Sam. 19.4, 5.
Yet muſt we neglect to reprove them for their Faults, Levit. 19.17. till they prove ſcorners or deſperate? Mat. 7.6.
* Can we rightly take care of our Neighbours good Name if we do not by a Holy walking, endeavour to preſerve our own? 1 Sam. 2.30. Eccl. 7.1.

div.p: Qu. Which is the Tenth Commandment?
Anſw. Thou ſhalt not Covet thy Neighbours Houſe, &c.

row.cell: §. ARE we forbidden not only the acts and ſetled thoughts of ſin, but even the firſt motions and ſtirrings thereof in our Souls? Rom. 7.7.

* May we comply with the Devils moti • ns. 〈…〉 5.3. or ſuffer our ſelves to be drawn aſide by o ••
〈…〉
to affect any thing forbidden by God's Law? Jam. 1.14.
* May we deſire what is anothers to his hurt, Acts 20.33. or envy our Neighbours happineſs, and delight in his loſs? Prov. 23.17, 18.
* Though we Covet not anothers Goods, may we ſet our affections on our own, or diſtract our mind and waſt our ſtrength in perſuit of the World? Luk. 12.15, 17.
Doth not Covetouſneſs bring a Curſe on the Goods, Bodies, Families, and Souls of Worldlings? Habak. 2.9, 10.
§. DOTH not this require all inward purity of the Soul, and the regulating our affections by the Word? Prov. 4.23.
Muſt we not rejoyce in our Neighbours proſperity Rom. 12.12. and be contented with what Condition the providence of God allots us? 1 Tim. 6.6, 8. Heb. 13.5.

p.hi: What doſt thou chiefly learn by theſe Commandments?
I learn two things: my duty towards God and my duty towards my Neighbour.

row.cell: §. WAS not the Law Written on two Tables, the one containing our Duty to God, the other our duty to men, and both Comprehended in Love? Exod. 34.1-5. Rom. 13.10.
Can thoſe two be ſeparated in our Practice and Obedience, or is our Holineſs true without righteouſneſs? Luk. 1.75.
Yet are not the duties of the firſt Table more noble than the duties of the Second, as the Object of them, which is God, is greater than Man? Job 33.12.

p.hi: What is thy duty towards God?

My duty towards God is to believe in him, to fear him, and to love him, with all my Heart, with all my
mind, with all my Soul, and with all my Strength: To Worſhip him to give him thanks, to put my whole truſt in him, to call upon him, to Honour his Holy Name and his word, and to ſerve him truly all the days of my Life.

row.cell: §. DOTH not the Four firſt Commandments make up the firſt Table, and is not Love to God the Sum of them all? Mat. 22.37, 38.
Can we Love God aright, if we Love him not for himſelf, and this with a Superlative Love? Luk. 14.26.
Can Faith be true that works not by Love, Gal. 5.6. or that Love real that ſhows not it Self in keeping his Commandments? Joh. 15.10, 14.
And doth not Love to God make our obedience more willing, chearful, active and abiding? 1 Joh. 5.3.
Seeing we cannot Love God without meaſure (as He is good without meaſure) ought we to Love him leſs, then with all our Heart, mind, might and Strength? Deut. 6.5.

p.hi: What is thy duty towards thy Neighbour?

My duty towards my Neighbour is to love him as my Self, and to do to all men, as I mould they ſhould do unto me; To love, honour, and ſuccour my Father and Mother. To honour, and obey the King, and all that are put in Authority under Him. To ſubmit my Self to all my Governours, Teachers, Spirital Paſters and Maſters. To order my Self lowly, and reverendly to all my Betters. To hurt no body by Word or Deed. To be true and juſt in all my Dealing. To bear no malice nor hatred in my Heart. To keep my Hands from picking and ſtealing, and my Tongue from evil ſpeaking, lying and ſtandering. To keep my Body in temperance, ſoberneſs and charity, not to covet, nor deſire other Mens Goods, but to learn and labour truly to get mine own living, and to do my duty, in that State of Life unto which it ſhall pleaſe God to call me.

row.cell: §. DOTH not the Second Table contain the Six Laſt Commandments, and is not Love to our Neighbour the Sum of them all? Mat. 22.39.

Are not all thoſe meant by our Neighbours, with whom
we have any Dealings or converſe? Luk. 10.29-36.
Muſt we not love our Neighbours, with a pure, hearty, and unfeigned love, as we love our ſelves? 1 Joh. 3.18.
Yet muſt we love all equally, with the ſame meaſure 〈◊〉 kind of love?

〈◊〉 is not natural affection due to Relations, 2 Tim. 3. • . • love of Reverence to Superiours, and of complacen
••
〈◊〉 delight, to the Godly? Pſal. 16.2.
* But muſt we deny a love of Compaſſion to all in miſery, and a love of Benevolence to our very Enemies? Luk. 6.32, 33.
† And can we do our duty required in theſe Comm •• dments without this Grace of love and Charity? 1 Cor. 13.1-7.
§. NOW you have heard theſe Commandments explained, do you think that you are able perfectly to fulfil the Law of God? Eccl. 7.20. Jam. 3.2.
Muſt you not lament your ſinfulneſs and weakneſs, and depend on Chriſt for Righteouſneſs and Strength? Iſa. 45.2 • .
And do you not ſtand to your promiſe, that in deſire and conſtant endeavour you will Practice ſincere obedience to God's Commandments? Pſal. 119.6, 48.

div.p: My good Child, know this that thou art not able to do theſe things of thy Self, nor to walk in the Commandments of God, and to ſerve him, without his ſpecial Grace, which thou muſt learn at all times to call for by diligent Prayer—

row.cell: §. IS not Prayer a neceſſary part of Worſhip in order to the obtaining Grace, Rom 10 13. and availing much, when perform'd aright▪ Jam. 5 16.

* Is there any other object of R ••• gi ••• Prayer, but God, who alone ſearcheth the Hear •
▪ 2 Chron 6.30.
* Is Prayer a bare ſpeaking the words with our Mouths, without the p •••• ng out the d •• i • es of our Hearts? Pſal. 25.1. and 42.4.
* May we omit any 〈◊〉 the kinds of Prayer, Publick in the Church, Acts 2.42 private in the Family, Jer. 10.25. and ſecret in the Cloſet? Mat. 6.6.
Muſt we not often lift up our Hearts in Holy Ejaculations, Pſal. 119.164. and ſometimes uſe extraordinary Prayer with Faſting? 1 Cor. 7.5.
* Muſt we not know the matter of our Prayers by our wants, but chiefly by the Precepts and Promiſes of God? Heb. 4.16. 1 Joh. 5.14.
* Have we any other Mediatour, whoſe name we can come in, ſave our Lord Jeſus Chriſt? Joh. 14.13, 14.
* Can we perform this duty aright without the Holy Spirit, to help our infirmities, Rom. 8.26. and to ſtir up Holy affections and Graces in the Soul? Zech. 12.10.
† Muſt we joyn with our deſires the Graces of Faith, Humility and Self-denyal; and are you deſirous ſo to Pray?

div.p: —Let me hear therefore if thou canſt ſay the Lords Prayer.

p.hi: Our Father which art in Heaven; Hallowed by thy name. Thy kingdom come. Thy will be done in Earth, as it is in Heaven. Give us this day our dayly bread. And forgive us our treſpaſſes, As we forgiven them that treſpaſs againſt us. And lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from evil.
For thine is the Kingdom, and the power and the Glory, for ever and ever. Amen.

row.cell: §. IS not this call'd the Lords Prayer, becauſe the Lord himſelf Compoſed it, and taught it his Diſciples?
* May we refuſe to uſe theſe words as a Form, ſo excellent for the Author, matter and method, and as being part of Chriſt's own word and Preſcription? Luk. 11.1, 2.
Yet ſeeing it is ſo general and Comprehenſive, Is it unlawful to uſe other words in Prayer?
* Is not this then a perfect Pattern of Prayer to direct us in the matter and manner of our Supplications? Mat. 6.9.

div.p: Qu. What is the Preface of the Lords Prayer?
Anſw. Our Father which art in Heaven.

row.cell: §. CAN there be a greater encouragement to come to God in Prayer, than this, that He is the Father of Believers by adoption? Luk. 11.13. Pſal. 103.13.
Is it not a fearful thing to come before God, without a Special Intereſt in him? Heb. 12.29.
Can we have acceſs to him any way but by Chriſt, Eph. 3.14. or have an evidence of our Intereſt, but by the Spirit of adoption? Gal. 4.6.
Doth not this Relation require dutiful affections, ſuch as filial fear, love and confidence when we draw near Him? Mala. 1.6.
§. MUST not they who ſay Our Father, live as the Children of one Father, Mat. 23.8. and Pray for and with one another? Jam. 5.16. Acts 20.36.
§. IS not the God to whom we Pray (though preſent every where, Pſal. 139.7, 8.) moſt gloriouſly preſent in the higheſt Heavens? Iſa. 63.15. and 66.1.
* Is there any thing which a God in Heaven cannot give, if it be good for us? Pſal. 115.3.
* Should not poor crawling worms come with a great awe and reverence before the God of Heaven? Eccl. 5.1, 2.
* Is it fit to have Earthly Hearts, when we Worſhip a Heavenly Father? Pſal. 123.1. Lam. 3.41.
* Is not the God of Heaven equally near to all his Petitioners in whatſoever parts of the Earth? Acts 17.27.

div.p: Qu. Which is the Firſt Petition?
Anſw. Hallowed be thy Name.

row.cell: §. IS not the Hallowing Gods Name, to Honour and Glorify Him in all things by which He makes himſelf known?
Can the Name of God be ever impure in it Self, or otherwiſe than Holy and glorious? Pſal. 8.1, 9.
Yet is not his Name diſhonoured by ſin, Rom. 3.23. and reproach'd and blaſphem'd by Sinners? Pſal. 74.10.
* Muſt we not beg Grace, to Hallow his Name in our Hearts; by acknowledging and honouring it, as Infinitely Holy? Iſa. 5.16.
Can we thus Sanctify his Name, unleſs he firſt Sanctify our Hearts and make them Holy? 1 Theſ. 5.23.
* Muſt we not deſire Grace, to Honour him with our mouths, Joſh. 7 19. Pſal. 69.30. and in our lives, by worſhipping and obeying Him? Jer. 13.16. Mat. 5.16.
* Can we honour his name aright, without deſiring that others alſo might Glorifie and hallow his name? Pſal. 145.21.
* Muſt we not beg that He would glorifie his own name in the World, Pſal. 67.1, 2, 3. and pull down what is Contrary to his Glory therein? Pſal. 83.16. &c. Pſal. 57.5.

div.p: Qu. Which is the Second Petition?
Anſw. Thy Kingdom come.

row.cell: §. HATH not God a general Kingdom over all, and muſt we not deſire that His Soveraign Authority may be every where acknowledged? Pſal. 103.19. Dan. 4.32.
Is it enough to be under his Providential Dominion (as are all creatures) unleſs we be made the Subjects of his Kingdom of Grace? 1 Theſ. 2.12. Mark. 1.15.
* Do you not beg then to be delivered from the Kingdom of Satan, under which you were by Nature, that Chriſt may Reign in you by his Grace and Spirit? Col. 1.13. Rom. 14.17.
And that He would make you fit for, and give you an abundant entrance into the Kingdom of Heaven? 2 Tim. 4.18.
* Are you to neglect others in your Prayers, ſo as not to deſire the ſpreading of the word of his Kingdom? 2 Theſ. 3.1.
* Is it not highly deſirable that the Kingdoms of the world ſhould be all the Kingdoms of Chriſt; and Jews and Gentiles given him for his poſſeſſion? Rev. 11.15.
Can we pray for this, without deſiring the pulling down of Antichriſt and all the implacable enemies of the Church? Pſal. 68.1.

* Muſt we not deſire the haſtning of his Kingdom of
Glory in which all the Saints ſhall have with him their perfect Conſummation and bliſs? Rev. 22.20.

div.p: Qu. Which is the Third Petition?
Anſw. Thy will be done in Earth, &c.
